structured_info.title_cn: 利用人工神经网络对反渗透脱盐过程进行精确建模、仿真与性能分析
structured_info.title_en: Employing artificial neural network for accurate modeling, simulation and performance analysis of an RO-based desalination process
structured_info.abstract: In this paper, we implement sustainable soft computing via application of Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) to predict the desalination plant output more accurately. The proposed ANN models have been trained with a backpropagation (BP) algorithm. Motivated by the literature, an exhaustive modeling has been performed using an extended list of six ANN modeling parameters that include number of hidden layers and their nodes, activation and training functions, dataset fractional allocation, and error analysis functions. For this, 4 suitable experimental inputs and permeate flux as output have been considered for the modeling investigation. The proposed models have been simulated in the MATLAB Simulink platform and compared with literature models, based on the regression coefficient (R2), errors, and iterations. An investigation of 127 trials leads to the optimal selection of the parameters that achieve higher optimal model performance (R2 ≥ 99.4%, Error ≤ 0.003) than the existing models in the literature. We have observed that choice of softmax-purelin function (activation function for hidden layer-output layer), two hidden layers with 20 nodes each, Levenberg Marquardt training function, dataset divisions (80% training: 10% validation: 10% testing) and the mean square error (MSE) demonstrate best model performance.
structured_info.methodology: Artificial Neural Networks trained with backpropagation algorithm; systematic variation of six modeling parameters (hidden layers, nodes, activation functions, training functions, dataset allocation, error functions); 127 experimental trials; MATLAB Simulink implementation; performance evaluation using regression coefficient (R2), mean square error, and iteration count.
structured_info.conclusion: Optimal ANN configuration (softmax-purelin activation, two hidden layers with 20 nodes each, Levenberg Marquardt training, 80-10-10 data split, MSE) achieves superior performance (R2=99.4%, error=0.003) over existing models. This approach enables accurate permeate flux prediction for efficient desalination plant control.

analysis.Overview: The paper develops an optimized Artificial Neural Network model to accurately predict permeate flux in reverse osmosis desalination plants, addressing water scarcity challenges through sustainable computing.
Background_and_Motivation: Global water scarcity despite abundant resources; limited performance of existing desalination plants; inability for real-time plant monitoring in developing regions.
Improve prediction accuracy of desalination plant output to optimize operations; address research gaps in ANN parameter utilization identified in literature.

Highlight urgent need for efficient water treatment solutions due to population growth and resource constraints; emphasize ANN's capability to handle complex, nonlinear datasets where traditional methods fail.
Position accurate plant modeling as critical for sustainable freshwater production, directly linking to UN Sustainable Development Goals for clean water access.
Contributes to sustainable computing, water treatment engineering, and machine learning applications in environmental systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: 1) Artificial Neural Network: Computational model inspired by biological neural networks. 2) Backpropagation Algorithm: Training method adjusting network weights based on error minimization. 3) Permeate Flux: Key performance metric (L/h·m²) measuring freshwater output in desalination.
ANN structure processes four input parameters (temperature, flow rate, salinity) through optimized hidden layers to predict permeate flux; parameter selection directly influences prediction accuracy.
Experimental data (Gil et al. 2018) sufficiently represents RO plant behavior; relationships between inputs/outputs are learnable through ANN despite process complexity.
Provides methodological innovation through comprehensive parameter optimization framework, advancing predictive modeling in desalination engineering.
Methodology: Feedforward ANN architecture with systematic testing of six parameters; 127 trials in MATLAB; Levenberg-Marquardt optimization; performance metrics (R2, MSE, iterations).
Novel incorporation of softmax activation and exhaustive parameter combinations; highly applicable to RO systems but generalizable to other membrane processes; justified through comparative analysis.

88 experimental datasets from prior study (Gil et al. 2018); inputs: condenser/evaporator temps, flow rate, salinity; output: permeate flux; normalized via mapminmax; 80-10-10 training-validation-testing split shows best representativeness.
Rigorous trial design examining parameter interactions; MSE and R2 provide comprehensive error/reliability assessment; 1000-iteration limit ensures computational efficiency.
Follows soft computing paradigm, emphasizing approximation and tolerance for imprecision over precise analytical models, suitable for complex environmental systems.
Results: Model 6 achieved optimal performance (R2=99.4%, MSE=0.003) with softmax-purelin activation, two 20-node hidden layers, LM training; required only 12 iterations; errors within ±0.2 range.
Results show exceptional stability across training/validation/testing phases; high R2 values (98.8-99.4%) consistently outperform literature benchmarks; minimal error range confirms reliability.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Problem-solution structure: water scarcity → desalination limitations → ANN optimization solution → experimental validation → performance comparison.
1) Identify research gaps in ANN parameter usage 2) Propose comprehensive parameter framework 3) Validate through systematic trials 4) Compare results with state-of-art 5) Demonstrate superiority.

Strength: Quantitative validation through 127 trials addresses potential overfitting concerns. Weakness: Limited discussion on computational load for real-time implementation; addressed through emphasis on low iteration counts.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Six-parameter optimization framework; novel softmax-purelin application; minimum iterations (12); 99.4% accuracy; comprehensive 127-trial validation.
Model trained on single dataset (Gil et al. 2018); generalizability to diverse plant configurations unverified; assumes static operational conditions.
Data-driven approach limits physical interpretability; focus on permeate flux overlooks other performance indicators like energy consumption or salt rejection.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positions as bridge between soft computing advances and sustainable water treatment; responds to identified gaps in ANN parameter utilization literature.
Specialized terminology (permeate flux, backpropagation, Levenberg-Marquardt); authoritative tone; strategic citations to establish methodology legitimacy and highlight novelty.
Builds authority through extensive literature review (27 references); citation patterns emphasize benchmarking against prior works to demonstrate incremental advancements.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Optimized ANN configuration significantly improves permeate flux prediction accuracy; systematic parameter analysis outperforms existing models; enables efficient desalination plant control.
Incorporate evolutionary algorithms (GA/PSO) for enhanced optimization; expand to multi-objective optimization including energy efficiency; validate across diverse plant configurations.
